awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical:

Semiconductor technologies have fueled the explosive growth of information-age technologies over the last half century. Further advances, however, are becoming increasingly difficult as devices dimensions approach atomic scales. This challenge requires new approaches that harness quantum phenomena. Novel electronic devices that exploit quantum properties have the potential for better device reliability and lower power consumption. Quantum technologies bring their own challenges. In particular, environmental effects can corrupt quantum information and significant resources are required for error correction. Topological materials offer great potential to address this problem because of their unique properties. In particular, quantum states are topologically protected by symmetries and are less subject to corruption. In this project elastic strain rather than electric or magnetic fields will be used to control electronic states in devices. Logic gates and other electronic devices are expected to be more reliable and use less power than conventional devices based on complementary metal oxide semiconductors. Interactive and engaging educational outreach programs will be integrated with the research project. These include Science Blog writing and Materials and Device Exhibits. These outreach efforts will promote scientific literacy to the general public and improve science appreciation by local K-12 students. This in turn will attract such students to modern science and technology in the early stages of their education. Finally, the participation of underrepresented groups in scientific research will be enhanced.

Technical:

This collaborative research project concerns novel strain-electronic (or straintronic) nanowire devices built upon two classes of topological materials, topological crystalline insulators (TCIs) and Weyl semimetals (WSMs), which host massless Dirac fermions on their surfaces and Weyl fermions with definite chirality in their bulk, respectively. These extraordinary surface or bulk states are topologically protected by symmetries and are rather robust against impurities, defects and disorder. Electronic devices exploiting these quantum/topological states are likely to have significantly improved reliability and/or reduced power consumption relative to conventional semiconductor-based electronics. The overall objective of this project is to study and manipulate the exotic quantum properties of Dirac and Weyl fermions in topological devices utilizing controllable elastic strain towards low-power, highly reliable electronic applications. In contrast to previous studies of bulk crystals and thin films, the proposed research will focus on nanowire/nanoribbon-based devices that harbor exceptional features for straintronic studies and applications. The success of the project will be built on the two PIs' existing collaboration, extensive familiarity with topological materials, and complementary expertise on material synthesis, device fabrication, magneto-transport studies, and theoretical modeling of electronic systems.  The combined theoretical and experimental studies of strain-driven topological phase transitions and associated quantum transport properties will offer new paradigms for fundamental, potentially exploitable physics in electronic systems. The proposed research is also anticipated to represent a key step in establishing a new research area, topological straintronics: the manipulation of topological quasi-particles with controllable elastic strain.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Topological materials are a class of quantum materials that host topologically protected states and exotic transport properties with great potential for novel electronic device applications. In this project, we performed synthesis of nanostructured topological materials, fabrication of nanodevices, and explored their physical properties as a function of strain, temperature, and magnetic field. Theoretical investigations focused on finding novel orderings in topological material settings, and on uncovering measurable impacts of the underlying quantum geometry they host. The outcomes of the project include:

Intellectual Merit: 1) Developed strain apparatuses/techniques that enable low temperature magneto-transport and Hall measurements, and room temperature Raman scattering measurement on nanodevices under the application of uniaxial strain. These apparatuses/techniques can be used for strain engineering of other nanomaterials beyond topological materials. 2) Realized bottom-up synthesis of high-quality, single crystalline topological nanowires that exhibit geometric effect in electron diffraction. Advanced the understanding of the metal-catalyzed growth of the (Pb,Sn)Te family of nanowires and achieved nanowires with high aspect ratios that are highly desired for strain transport studies.  3) Achieved a better understanding of the electrical transport properties of topological nanodevices under the influence of strain and chemical doping. Advanced the understanding of the crystal structure - physical property relations in nanostructured telluride systems and the impact of electron correlation on the transport properties of topological semimetal nanowires. 4) Developed theoretical descriptions of new types of orderings in low-dimensional materials that are impacted by their non-trivial quantum geometry and topology. In twisted graphene systems this included stripe skyrmion states that can be stabilized by uni-axial strain, partially spin-polarized Hofstadter states with electric-field tunable transport properties, and new types of self-similar electronic structure for systems without a magnetic field.  5) Studies of collective modes in transition metal dichalcogenides and graphene uncovered new ways to control the dynamics of excitons and plasmons in nanowires and two-dimensional materials by exploiting their quantum geometric properties.  6) Heterostructures involving Weyl semimetal surfaces yielded new proposals of valleytronic and plasmonic devices, as well as new concepts for impurity-induced magnetism in thin Weyl semimetal films.

Broader Impacts: 1) The project offered great opportunities for the training and development of both undergraduate and graduate students (including a female student and an underrepresented minority student) in STEM. In particular, one of the undergraduates published three peer-reviewed papers with the PIs; a female student who was one of the major contributors to the project has recently graduated with a Ph.D. degree in physics and has started her new job as a scientist; a minority student in the APS bridge program obtained his master’s degree and started his Ph.D. journey in another institute. 2) Outreach activities, such as science blog writing, lab tours, and demo videos, promoted scientific literacy, helped develop appreciation of science by the general public, and attracted K-12 students to STEM.  They also encouraged undergraduate and graduate students to engage the general public and younger generations through effective scientific writing and/or presentation.
